Replace.Text: Sayyida al Hurra Exploration Legend Diplomatic
For this Age, gain +15% [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence at the cost of -2 Combat Strength for your Naval Units
Sayyida al Hurra Exploration Legend Militaristic
For this Age, +3 Combat Strength for your Naval Units at the cost of -10% [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence
Sayyida al Hurra Modern Legend Diplomatic
For this Age, gain +15% [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence at the cost of -2 Combat Strength for your Air Units
Sayyida al Hurra Modern Legend Militaristic
For this Age, +3 Combat Strength for your Air Units at the cost of -10% [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence

Legend Unlock. +25% [icon:RELATIONSHIP] Relationship from starting or supporting [icon:ENDEAVOR] Endeavors. -25% [icon:RELATIONSHIP] Relationship from starting [icon:SANCTIONS] Sanctions or rejecting [icon:ENDEAVOR] Endeavors
Legend Unlock. +5 [icon:NAR_REW_COMBAT] Combat Strength for all Units against [icon:CITY_FORTIFIED] Fortified Districts

At the end of the 15th century, Morocco was undergoing tumultuous change. The Marinid dynasty, one of several Berber empires that rose in North Africa in the wake of the Islamic caliphates, had controlled much of the western edge of the Maghreb for two centuries. By the 1470s, they were replaced by the Wattasid dynasty. But Morocco was stumbling. The Portuguese, seeking control of Gibraltar and a sea route around Africa, captured many coastal settlements, curtailing trade opportunities, while decades of chaos had undermined the economic and cultural prosperity of the region. In 1492, the Emirate of Granada fell to Catholic Spain, ending the Reconquista and dealing a further blow to Muslim power in North Africa

In 1471, a kasbah was founded at Chefchaouen by Ali ibn Rashid al-Alami, a former soldier who had fought in Granada during the Reconquista. The settlement quickly attracted exiles from Granada as the Emirate fell, and grew into a thriving city. Located inland from the northern coast near Gibraltar, Chefchaouen was in a prime position to challenge the Portuguese. The city was home to both local resistance fighters knowledgeable in mountainous terrain and exiles from Granada who arrived with expertise in coastal defense. Under the governance of al-Alami, this influx of Granadans imbued Chefchaouen with a mixture of Andalusian and Moroccan culture

Al-Alami’s daughter, born sometime between 1491 and 1495, grew up between these two traditions. Her real name is disputed in the sources, but she came to be known as Sayyida al Hurra, the “Noble Lady.” Her childhood was stable, and she received a thorough education from some of Granada’s finest scholars. In 1510, she married Sidi al-Mandri II, ruler of Tétouan. This city, north of Chefchaouen, presided over a critical stretch of coastline. By the 14th century, it had become a haven for pirates and was destroyed twice by Iberian powers, first by Castille in 1399, then by the Portuguese in 1426. After the fall of Granada, Sidi al-Mandri’s uncle, Ali al-Mandri, and his followers settled in the city’s ruins and began to rebuild. These efforts were aided by al-Alami of nearby Chefchaouen, forging a close alliance between the two men and their respective cities that was further strengthened by the interfamilial marriage

Sayyida al Hurra seems to have begun her political career during her marriage to al-Mandri. Tensions were high between Tétouan and nearby Ceuta, a Portuguese stronghold along the Strait of Gibraltar. Al-Mandri appears to have entrusted his wife with a prominent voice in his government, and for good reason. In addition to her powerful familial connections, she had grown up watching her father rule Chefchaouen, and her education included proficiency in Portuguese and Spanish. During their marriage, she may have ruled the city in her husband’s stead when he was away traveling

Upon al-Mandri’s death in 1515 (or 1519), Sayyida al Hurra became the sole and undisputed ruler of Tétouan. During this period, she received the moniker “al Hurra,” a title given to women in power across the Islamic world. As Tétouan’s governor, she inherited the responsibilities of not only fostering the city’s continued rebirth, but also the ongoing struggle against Portugal and Spain. These relations were always fraught, and European sources portray her as a clever and well-respected diplomat, though at times verbally aggressive with Ceuta’s Portuguese ruler

Sayyida al Hurra’s most famous claim to fame today is her association with pirates. Despite Tétouan’s local strength as a city-state, the population was still small, unable to field a large army or navy. Moreover, Iberian dominance of the coast had left the Moroccan resistance disadvantaged in naval conflict, especially when faced with large European fleets

However, there was another strong naval power in the region – the Barbary corsairs. These pirates emerged from North Africa during the Middle Ages, but they became far more organized and dangerous by the end of the 15th century, a rise accelerated by the expansion of the Ottoman Empire. The Ottomans had claimed the caliphate title as the leader of the Islamic world, while Spain had positioned itself as the leader of the Christian world. The two powers clashed vehemently during this era, particularly through naval conflict in the Mediterranean. Although the Barbary corsairs were a multinational community, their operations were based in Ottoman territories, and they became increasingly associated with the empire. Overlap between the corsairs and the Ottoman navy was not unusual – some pirates served as privateers, while others eventually joined the navy as officers. And their attacks on Iberian ships and settlements also found them fighting side by side with local North African populations struggling against the same enemies

Alliances between Sayyida al Hurra and the Barbary corsairs were mutually beneficial. Sayyida al Hurra gained a stronger military presence in the area as well as greater control of the surrounding sea; importantly, Tétouan also benefited economically from corsair raids on merchant ships. Meanwhile, Tétouan was one of the only ports in Morocco that remained independent of Portugal or Spain, making it a safe harbor in the western Mediterranean for pirates restocking their ships or launching attacks. Her most famous associate was Hayreddin Barbarossa, a powerful Ottoman pirate who later became a naval admiral

Sayyida al Hurra ruled Tétouan alone for over two decades before she remarried, this time to Sultan Ahmed al-Wattassi in 1541. The Sultanate was based in Fez, but on her demand, the ceremony took place in Tétouan – this was the only time a Moroccan sultan married outside of his capital, a testament to Sayyida al Hurra’s power and the respect she commanded. The marriage seems to have been primarily political in nature, adding royal legitimacy to her authority while allowing the Wattasid dynasty to consolidate power in the north. After the ceremony, Ahmed al-Wattassi returned to Fez, leaving Sayyida al Hurra to continue her solo reign

But the Wattasid dynasty was in decline, and the marriage was not enough to preserve her power. Only a year later, in 1542, Sayyida al Hurra’s son-in-law from her first marriage seized Tétouan and exiled her. She returned to her hometown Chefchaouen, where she led a quiet life until her death in 1552
I have sailed through treacherous waters and always emerged victorious.
Witness me, and see why my people accept me as leader.
Witness me, and see why my people accept me as leader.
Witness me, and see why my people accept me as leader.
Your mistakes brought you here. No second chance awaits.
I will not be trapped between an unforgiving sea and a tyrant.
Leave me with my citizens. I follow their fate.
I am pleased to see where your loyalties lie.
What factions favor you? Take this insult to them.

Receive the strongest Naval Unit every time you succeed in an [icon:ESPIONAGE] Espionage Action, if you can place a Naval Unit. +2 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture and +1 [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence per Age for every Naval Unit stationed on a [icon:CITY_URBAN] District. No [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence penalty for your [icon:ESPIONAGE] Espionage being revealed. Opponents cannot use Counter Spy against you

[BLIST][LI]Receive the strongest [B]Naval Unit [/B]every time you succeed in an [B][icon:ESPIONAGE] Espionage Action[/B], if you can place a Naval Unit.[LI][B]+2 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture[/B] and [B]+1 [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence[/B] per Age for every [B]Naval Unit[/B] stationed on a [icon:CITY_URBAN] [B]District [/B]. [LI]No [B][icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence[/B] penalty for your [B][icon:ESPIONAGE] Espionage[/B] being revealed. [LI]Opponents cannot use [B]Counter Spy[/B] against you.[/LIST]
Likes the Civilization with the smallest number of Naval Units. Dislikes the one with the greatest number of Naval Units

Sayyida al Hurra, champion of the people, you are the force that keeps the enemy at bay. By silver tongue or cannonfire, all challenges sink before you. Yet even in the darkest times, your gentle hand guides cities to greatness. Raise your sail and show the world what it means to lead
A blade for land and ship
+2 [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold Per Age in Settlements with a Naval Unit stationed on a District
Gain 25 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture per Age for every Diplomatic Action accepted by another Leader
As Sayyida al Hurra, complete the Pax Imperatoria Legacy Path
As Sayyida al Hurra, complete the Pax Imperatoria Legacy Path twice
As Sayyida al Hurra, complete the Pax Imperatoria Legacy Path thrice

As Sayyida al Hurra, reach at least 2 Legacy Path Milestones
As Sayyida al Hurra, reach at least 3 Legacy Path Milestones
As Sayyida al Hurra, complete the Great Library Legacy Path
As Sayyida al Hurra, complete the Great Library Legacy Path twice
As Sayyida al Hurra, complete the Great Library Legacy Path thrice

As Sayyida al Hurra in Antiquity, complete a quest to make a new friend
As Sayyida al Hurra in Antiquity, complete a quest to build up a city's culture

As Sayyida al Hurra in Exploration, complete a quest to help strangers in need
As Sayyida al Hurra in Modern, complete a quest to restore the people's trust
As Sayyida al Hurra in Modern, complete a quest to uncover stories of the past
Contains a new Leader, Sayyida al Hurra
Sayyida al Hurra’s crew steer their ship towards the much larger craft. As the vessels match speed, a grappling hook makes contact – and then another, launching a cacophony of steel sinking into wood
A master negotiator, Sayyida al Hurra is stunned by the diplomatic rejection. There are few reasons to deny her, especially when the prospect of gold is involved
The sea is an endless bounty
Atop the mainmast, a lookout frantically signals the captain when he spots a ship flying Sayyida al Hurra's flag on the horizon. More vessels emerge one by one until her fleet dominates the skyline
Their captain makes for a fine ransom

The monument-carver hands the chisel to his queen for the final strokes. She pauses to think before the hammer falls, repeatedly, in a frenzy. When she is done, she has not carved her birth name, Lalla Aisha, but Sayyida al Hurra. The free lady
The legend of Sayyida al Hurra extends outward, inspiring others
In the shade of the wonder, a new home begins to grow
To be friendly with Sayyida al Hurra has come to mean trade and prosperity. It is far preferable to being her enemy
A good first step to an alliance

Sayyida al Hurra concludes the negotiations – neither party shall take hostile action against the other. While she, being a good diplomat, has surrendered her scimitar to the guard, she has been careful to leave the hilt of her yatagan visible from her boot
Sayyida al Hurra slips into the bustle of the cultural quarter, trying to remain discreet. The buzz of art, drama, and community surrounds her
This, though wonderful, is not yet greatness

The newly finished wonder serves as the backdrop for song and dance. Making no effort to conceal herself this time, Sayyida al Hurra accepts celebratory mint tea and joins her people in the festivities
A little pragmatism goes a long way

With ships anchored and restless bodies now ashore, it is hard to say where the waterfront ends and the city begins. As the more experienced of Sayyida al Hurra’s crew happily take their leave, it leaves a few itching for something to do
Round up the restless and take them on an excursion
Enforce a rest period, the crew needs it

Where Spain and Sayyida al Hurra stand is murky. Like when sand stirs the ocean floor, leaving nothing to interpret but bits of shell. Relationships are a continuous effort – and it's clear she will extend little
The scorn is warranted, and others shall be warned
The pirates sailing under Sayyida al Hurra overwhelm the captured vessel, heedless of its flag. As the crew secures the ship, the captain turns their attention to the drenched captives
Take any valuables they may have
Returning home with stolen riches, the captain is surprised by the split response Sayyida al Hurra's people have for the unlucky crew
Remind them the captives were conscripted
Where Spain goes, coercion follows, and always to their own benefit. Sayyida al Hurra will not be intimidated

Rain falls sideways like daggers onto bodies already felled by swords of steel. The forces behind this assault seek to take the captain hostage, but he has other plans - one where he goes down swinging
A hard lesson, but a necessary one
See that the families are taken care of
Plumes of smoke rise everywhere, harbingers of Sayyida al Hurra’s armies. They march and sail wherever they please, take whatever they want, and leave behind a husk of what once was
Keep raiding and damn the consequences
+25% Yields and HP from Pillaging, but -25 [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence when you Pillage
Peace talks are never out of the question
Word of the {1_SUBJECT_CIVILIZATION_ADJ} rejection sends Sayyida al Hurra’s crew into a frenzy. She tempers their reaction with a glance, knowing they yearn for retribution
Let this be a warning to others

Sayyida al Hurra has heard rumblings of this Republic of Pirates. Their captains see to all matters aboard their ships – the equal distribution of gold, insurance for the wounded, casting votes for important matters..
It is an admirable code of conduct
As {1_SUBJECT_CIVILIZATION_ADJ} relations warm, Sayyida al Hurra takes note of the stark difference in naval power. Her fleets circle theirs as sharks circle minnows
The fleet commander awaits his lady's orders – carry a message of cooperation and trade, or tell tales of the greatness and beauty of Sayyida al Hurra's cities?

Laborers work the pumps in an endless toil. When one grows too tired, another rushes to take his place. The great ship lies exposed, carpenters crowding its hull like flies. When it is completed, it will go far
Sayyida al Hurra's trade ships return to her shores with goods of all sorts – and the good will of her trading partners

Sayyida al Hurra looks for respite from the cheering crowds of the rally, and overhears a pair of courtiers around a corner. Thinking themselves alone, they whisper salacious rumors of their leader's incompetence…
Find the source of the rumors
Spies learn the rumors being spread about Sayyida al Hurra are harmless, ranging from humorous to impossible. Humbling, but not a threat

Feet stomp to the beat of a drum, and voices join in with poetry. Sayyida al Hurra oversees the festivities when her fleet commander returns with a group of people huddled together, eyes sunken and wearing tattered clothes
Help them. This could be any of us
New hospitals provide for new migrants – Sayyida al Hurra knows what it means to be a stranger in need

Pilgrimage paths cut through Sayyida al Hurra's lands, crossing from holy temple to holy temple. But the faithful in Sayyida al Hurra's overseas settlments begin to wonder about their own role in the faith – surely those far from home could use some inspiration
+2 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture in Settlements per Great Work Slotted
There is holiness near and far. Even the sea is blessed

In Sayyida's shipyard, deft hands work with titanium, curving and caressing the material under extreme heat. The engineer's blueprint shows a massive structure not unlike a ship, with a crude doodle of a pirate peeking through the periscope, looking for their next target
A new age of piracy has begun!
Rumors of a stealth unit puts fear into other Civilizations
{1_Capital} is Sayyida al Hurra’s crowning jewel, yet buildings crumble and busy streets are pockmarked with holes. Her citizens deserve to enjoy modern luxuries, not cracked walls and chipped paint
Sayyida al Hurra’s corsairs come from all over Ottoman Empire, eager to sail under her banner. Glorious raids are led by massive and powerful fleets, capable of striking fear and awe
Share the spoils among the crew
Pocket most of the gold before sharing
Advisors close windows as they wait for Sayyida al Hurra. Shouting from unhappy citizens questioning their leader fills the street
Sayyida al Hurra restores her people’s faith by setting up an appeals system. Members of the community can now voice their opinions on decisions made for their empire
Be at +4 War Support in a war and have no Wars with Negative War Support
Sayyida al Hurra has always been a stranger. Here, in the dust of an archaeological dig, she finds other stories of other pasts, other homes lost to time
Sayyida al Hurra displays the artifacts the way they were found – chipped bowls and cracked vases tell the story of lives lived and lost to the destroying angel of history
As Sayyida al Hurra, access a new Exploration Legacy Card:[n] +15% Influence, -2 Combat Strength for Naval Units
As Sayyida al Hurra, access a new Exploration Legacy Card:[n] +3 Combat Strength for your Naval Units, -10% Influence
As Sayyida al Hurra, access a new Modern Legacy Card:[n] +15% Influence, -2 Combat Strength for Air Units
As Sayyida al Hurra, access a new Modern Legacy Card:[n] +3 Combat Strength for your Air Units, -10% Influence
+5 Combat Strength for all Units against Districts
+25% Relationship from starting or supporting Endeavors. -25% Relationship from starting Sanctions or rejecting Endeavors
[B]Sayyida al Hurra[/B] was from the same region as [B]Carthage[/B]
[B]Sayyida al Hurra[/B] was from the same region as the [B]Abbasids[/B]
The [B]Republic of Pirates[/B] strategically complements [B]Sayyida al Hurra[/B]
